column1: TA2.11;The amount of renewable fuels and renewable electricity supplied to the transport sector leads to a: (i) share of renewable energy within the final consumption of energy in the transport sector of at least 29 % by 2030; or (ii) GHG intensity reduction of at least 14.5 % by 2030
column2: compared to the baseline set out in Article 27(1)
column3: in accordance with an indicative trajectory set by the Member State.;TA3.1;+;The implementation of TA2.11 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.1
column4: as the increased use of renewable fuels and electricity in the transport sector can lead to a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions
column5: which in turn can help reduce pollution and promote a healthier environment
column6: ultimately contributing to the goal of halving the amount of residual municipal waste by 2030.;The connection between these two targets is based on the idea that reducing emissions in one sector can have a positive impact on other environmental goals

column1: TA2.13;The share of renewable energy in the electricity mix should double to 55-60%
column2: and projections show a share of around 84% by 2050.;TA3.8;+;The implementation of TA2.13 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.8
column3: as the increased share of renewable energy in the electricity mix can lead to a reduction in the EU's extraction capacity needs
column4: thereby promoting the development of recycling technologies and reducing waste.;This connection is based on the idea that increasing renewable energy production can reduce the demand for primary materials
column5: leading to a more circular economy.

column1: TA2.14;Each Member State shall increase the share of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector by at least 0.8 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the period 2021 to 2025 and by at least 1.1 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the period 2026 to 2030.;TA3.9;+;The implementation of TA2.14 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.9
column2: as the increased use of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector can lead to a reduction in the EU's processing capacity needs
column3: thereby promoting the development of recycling technologies and reducing waste.;This connection is based on the idea that increasing renewable energy production can reduce the demand for primary materials
column4: leading to a more circular economy.

column2: achieve 18% of the total increase in the share of energy from renewable sources between that Member State’s binding 2020 national target
column3: and its contribution to the 2030 target of the share of energy from renewable sources in gross final consumption of energy.;TA3.12;-;The implementation of TA2.15 may have a negative impact on TA3.12
column4: as the focus on achieving short-term renewable energy targets may divert attention and resources away from the development of manufacturing capacity for strategic net-zero technologies.;This connection is based on the idea that prioritizing short-term goals may come at the expense of long-term investments in critical technologies.

column1: TA2.16;Member States shall endeavour to increase the share of renewable sources in the amount of energy sources used for final energy and non-energy purposes in the industry sector by an indicative increase of at least 1.6 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the periods 2021 to 2025 and 2026 to 2030.;TA3.13;+;The implementation of TA2.16 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.13
column2: as the increased use of renewable energy in the industry sector can lead to a reduction in waste generation and promote the development of recycling technologies.;This connection is based on the idea that increasing renewable energy production can reduce the demand for primary materials
column3: leading to a more circular economy.

column1: TA2.17;A target of 15% electricity interconnection for 2030;TA3.15;+;The implementation of TA2.17 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.15
column2: as increased electricity interconnection can facilitate the exchange of renewable energy between countries
column3: promoting the development of a more integrated and efficient energy system.;This connection is based on the idea that increased interconnection can lead to a more resilient and sustainable energy system.

column1: TA2.21;Member States shall ensure that the total final energy consumption of all public bodies combined is reduced by at least 1.9% each year
column2: when compared to 2021.;TA3.18;-;The implementation of TA2.21 may have a negative impact on TA3.18
column3: as the focus on reducing energy consumption in public bodies may divert attention and resources away from the development of recycling technologies for industrial batteries.;This connection is based on the idea that prioritizing energy efficiency may come at the expense of investments in critical technologies.

column1: TA2.22;Member States shall collectively ensure a reduction of energy consumption of at least 11.7% in 2030 compared to the projections of the 2020 EU Reference Scenario.;TA3.19;+;The implementation of TA2.22 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.19
column2: as the reduction in energy consumption can lead to a decrease in electronic waste generation
column3: promoting the development of recycling technologies and reducing waste.;This connection is based on the idea that reducing energy consumption can lead to a reduction in waste generation.

column1: TA2.23;Member States shall make efforts to collectively contribute to the indicative Union primary energy consumption target amounting to no more than 992.5 Mtoe in 2030.;TA3.20;+;The implementation of TA2.23 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.20
column2: as the reduction in primary energy consumption can lead to a decrease in waste generation
column3: promoting the development of recycling technologies and reducing waste.;This connection is based on the idea that reducing primary energy consumption can lead to a reduction in waste generation.

column1: TA2.24;Each Member State shall ensure that at least 3% of the total floor area of heated and/or cooled buildings that are owned by public bodies is renovated each year to be transformed into at least nearly zero-energy buildings or zero-emission buildings.;TA3.21;+;The implementation of TA2.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.21
column2: as the renovation of public buildings can lead to a reduction in waste generation
column3: promoting the development of recycling technologies and reducing waste.;This connection is based on the idea that reducing waste generation in public buildings can lead to a reduction in waste generation overall.

column1: TA2.25;Reduce buildings’ final energy consumption by 14%;TA3.22;+;The implementation of TA2.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.22

column1: TA2.26;At least double the annual energy renovation rate of residential and non-residential buildings by 2030 and to foster deep energy renovations.;TA3.23;-;The implementation of TA2.26 may have a negative impact on TA3.23

column1: TA3.1;Halve the amount of residual (non-recycled) municipal waste by 2030;TA2.11;-;The implementation of TA3.1 may have a negative impact on TA2.11
